sections.title: From MCP mess to context management.

features.title: One endpoint for all your context
features.problemDescription: Stop wiring every client to every MCP.
features.highlightedText: The MCP Mesh collapses tool access into a single governed endpoint
features.complementText: , so any MCP-capable client (Cursor, Claude, internal agents) can use the same context layer with one integration.

features.title: Policy + audit trails, enforced at the control plane
features.problemDescription: Security and compliance can't live in every app.
features.highlightedText: The MCP Mesh enforces RBAC, policies, and approvals before execution
features.complementText: , and writes an immutable audit trail for every model and tool call.

features.title: Observability you can operate
features.problemDescription: When something breaks, or spend spikes, you need one answer to: what ran, where, why, and what did it cost?
features.highlightedText: The MCP Mesh provides unified logs, traces, latency, error rates, and attribution

features.title: Runtime strategies for cost, latency, and accuracy
features.problemDescription: As your tool surface grows, naive tool discovery becomes expensive and slow.
features.highlightedText: The MCP Mesh gives you different strategies for different needs, including code execution and smart routing

features.title: Swap MCPs without rewrites
features.problemDescription: Adopting MCP shouldn't mean picking a vendor forever.
features.highlightedText: Bindings define common interfaces for capabilities, so your apps target the contract, not the provider.
features.complementText: Replace one MCP with another and keep your UI, workflows, and agents unchanged.

sections.description: Run it on your infra, audit the code, and control context end-to-end—no lock-in. Kubernetes-native. Or run it as a self-hosted binary or container: laptop, IoT, cloud, on-prem—anywhere.

faqItems.question: Isn't this just an MCP proxy?
faqItems.answer: No. A proxy forwards traffic. A mesh adds dynamic routing, distributed policy enforcement, and composability—so auth, observability, and security become shared infrastructure across all MCP traffic.

faqItems.question: Will this lock us in?
faqItems.answer: It's designed for the opposite: open-source, self-hosted, Kubernetes-native, deployable in your infrastructure. Your MCPs and clients stay portable, and you can audit or fork as needed.

faqItems.question: Does it work with our existing AI tools?
faqItems.answer: Yes—the goal is universal compatibility: connect once and use your governed endpoint from any MCP-capable client (e.g., IDEs, desktop clients, custom agents).

faqItems.question: How do you handle credentials and access?
faqItems.answer: Credentials go into a centralized vault; access is enforced through enterprise auth and RBAC at the model/MCP/tool level, with policy checks before execution and audit trails for compliance.
